author: The Virginian-Pilot
title: U.S. Open 9-Ball Championships held in downtown Norfolk for first time
text:
NORFOLK Four decades ago, Barry Behrman scraped together 16 players and held a 9-ball tournament at a Norfolk billiards hall.
Beginning Sunday, he will host the 40th edition of the event - the U.S. Open 9-Ball Championships - and for the first time, it's being held in downtown Norfolk.
The six-day event at Sheraton Norfolk Waterside bears little resemblance to the modest beginnings of the U.S. Open. Behrman said he wasn't able to get a 16th player for that first tournament until the last minute, but the field for this year's event features 128 players from more than 20 countries.
While players chased a $3,000 top prize that first year, they will be competing for $188,000 this year, including $40,000 to the winner.
Much of the attention will be focused on Shane Van Boening of South Dakota, the only player to win three straight U.S. Open titles. He'll be chasing his fourth in a row this year.
Finland's Mike Immonen and England's Darren Appleton, who both own back-to-back championships, are among the top contenders. In fact, Van Boening, Immonen and Appleton have combined to win every U.S. Open title since 2006.
A win by Van Boening would tie him with Earl Strickland for the most all-time victories in the event at five.
The American is coming off a loss last month in the finals of the World 9-Ball Championships in Qatar. Taiwan's Pin-Yi Ko, ranked No. 1 by the World Pool-Billiards Association, won that event and is entered in the U.S. Open field.
Play begins at 10:30 a.m. Sunday. Through Thursday, there are daily sessions at 10:30 a.m., 12:30 and 2:30 p.m. Night sessions run at 7, 9 and 11 p.m. Friday's schedule consists of quarterfinals at 1 p.m., semifinals at 3 p.m. and the 7 p.m. final.
Tickets are $10 per session.
